docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Peres and Arafat Meet At European Gathering The Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, met for the second time in three days, joining European Union officials for an informal evening gathering in Brussels. While the men discussed Middle East issues, Mr. Peres is under instructions from the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, to refrain from substantive negotiations with Mr. Arafat for now. In the absence of high-level American engagement in the Middle East, the European Union is seeking to provide the Arab world with at least an impression of movement in the peace process. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: On the final day of campaigning in the New Jersey governor's race, Bret D. Schundler said today that his first priority in office would be to ready the state for a major bioterrorism attack, perhaps involving smallpox or plague. His opponent, James E. McGreevey, spent a third day sequestered with his wife, who was hospitalized over the weekend with pregnancy complications. In a news conference at the State House this afternoon, Mr. Schundler, the Republican candidate, outlined an eight-point plan for dealing with the increased threat of bioterrorism. He proposed training doctors to recognize outbreaks caused by biological agents, creating a centralized state bioterror response unit, increasing supplies of antibiotics at hospitals, and accelerating production of vaccines.

headline.main: Schundler Puts Bioterror Plan Atop Agenda

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. David Satcher, the surgeon general of the United States, says he plans to leave office when his term expires, on Feb. 13. ''I've been saying for several months that I was going to serve out my term, and my term ends on Feb. 13,'' Dr. Satcher said. ''I haven't made a big issue out of it.''

headline.main: No Second Term for Surgeon General

docs.lead_paragraph: Some women with diseases related to immune system malfunctions find that their symptoms subside during pregnancy, then rebound after childbirth. A new study at the National Institutes of Health suggests that the cycle may be caused by steps the pregnant woman's body takes to regulate stress and protect the fetus from being rejected by the mother's body.
docs.abstract: Study finds that symptoms experienced by women with diseases related to immune system malfunctions subside during pregnancy and rebound after childbirth; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Israel Begins Pullout Despite Gunman's Attack Israeli forces began pulling out from a Palestinian-controlled city in the West Bank, despite an attack by a Palestinian gunman, who emptied a semiautomatic rifle into a city bus in Jerusalem, killing two teenagers and injuring dozens of other people. An Israeli Army official said that the withdrawal had begun from Qalqilya, one of four Palestinian-controlled cities in which Israeli troops remained. A1 Nicaragua Awaits Vote Results Nicaraguans voted on whether to return the Sandinista leader, Daniel Ortega, pictured, to the presidency he lost in 1990, or to elect a Liberal Party stalwart and businessman, Enrique Bolaños. The two candidates were statistically tied in opinion polls. Results were not expected until today. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: James E. McGreevey canceled campaign events today for the second day in a row to be with his wife, Dina, who remained hospitalized with pregnancy complications, campaign aides and local hospital officials said. Mrs. McGreevey's condition, which was described as stable, raised the possibility that her husband would not be seen in public in the final days of his campaign for New Jersey governor. Aides said that it was uncertain whether Mr. McGreevey, the Democratic nominee, who is leading widely in the polls, would attend political events on Monday or if he would be available on election night Tuesday. ''We're taking it day by day,'' said Richard McGrath, a campaign spokesman.

headline.main: McGreevey Cancels Events as Pregnancy Keeps Wife in the Hospital

docs.lead_paragraph: James E. McGreevey canceled most of his weekend campaign appearances to be with his wife, Dina, who was hospitalized today for observation relating to her pregnancy. Mrs. McGreevey was in stable condition at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick this evening, according to hospital officials.

docs.lead_paragraph: FALLING ANGELS By Tracy Chevalier 324 pages. Dutton. $24.95. Tracy Chevalier's first novel, ''Girl With a Pearl Earring'' (2000), was a marvel of elliptical storytelling -- a novel that conjured the world of Johannes Vermeer with the painter's own fidelity to domestic detail and instinctive sense of ambient light. Though Ms. Chevalier's story of a young woman who goes to work as a maid in the painter's house was, at heart, a bildungsroman, the novel also illuminated Vermeer's alchemical art while coyly opening a window on 17th-century Delft.

headline.main: Trysting in a Cemetery Where Death Is a Metaphor

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 13. Now Playing ''BANDITS,'' starring Bruce Willis, Billy Bob Thornton and Cate Blanchett. Directed by Barry Levinson (PG-13, 123 minutes). This shaggy-dog romantic heist comedy feels like a modern Classics Illustrated version of ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid'' and ''Bonnie and Clyde.'' It stars Mr. Willis and Mr. Thornton as charming bank robbers who don't resort to violence. They get involved in a semi-ménage à trois with Kate (Ms. Blanchett), a depressed housewife who ends up joining the boys on their rapidly swelling legendary crime spree. But ''Bandits'' is guilty of behaving like a petty thievery corporation; it steals from so many sources that we're forced to realize that it has little of its own to offer. As such, it can't help but fail to meet expectations, given the talents involved (Elvis Mitchell).

docs.lead_paragraph: Riding in Cars With Boys Drew Barrymore, Cody Arens, Steve Zahn, Brittany Murphy, James Woods, Adam Garcia Directed by Penny Marshall PG-13 122 minutes Virtually moments after his birth, the son of Beverly D'Onofrio (Ms. Barrymore) has it all spelled out for him by his grandfather (Mr. Woods). ''Your mother is 15; your father is an idiot,'' the elder D'Onofrio, a hidebound police officer, tells the baby.
